fact: beryl, a mineral (ultimately from the name of Belur in southern India)
name: Beryllium

fact: English soda (the symbol Na is derived from New Latin natrium, coined from German Natron, 'natron')
name: Sodium

fact: Magnesia, a district of Eastern Thessaly in Greece
name: Magnesium

fact: alumina, from Latin alumen (gen. aluminis), 'bitter salt, alum'
name: Aluminium

fact: New Latin potassa, 'potash' (the symbol K is derived from Latin kalium)
name: Potassium

fact: Titans, the sons of the Earth Goddess of Greek mythology
name: Titanium

fact: Vanadis, an Old Norse name for the Scandinavian Goddess Freyja
name: Vanadium

fact: corrupted from magnesia negra; see Magnesium
name: Manganese

fact: English word (the symbol Fe is derived from Latin ferrum)
name: Iron

fact: Nickel, a mischievous sprite of German miner mythology
name: Nickel

fact: English word, from Latin cuprum, from Ancient Greek Kypros 'Cyprus'
name: Copper

fact: Most likely from German Zinke, 'prong' or 'tooth', though some suggest Persian sang, 'stone'
name: Zinc

fact: French arsenic, from Greek arsenikon 'yellow arsenic' (influenced by arsenikos, 'masculine' or 'virile'), from a West Asian wanderword ultimately from Old Iranian *zarniya-ka, 'golden'
name: Arsenic

fact: Niobe, daughter of king Tantalus from Greek mythology
name: Niobium

fact: Greek molybdaina, 'piece of lead', from molybdos, 'lead'
name: Molybdenum

fact: the asteroid Pallas, considered a planet at the time
name: Palladium

fact: English word (The symbol derives from Latin argentum)
name: Silver

fact: New Latin cadmia, from King Kadmos
name: Cadmium

fact: Latin indicum, 'indigo' (colour found in its spectrum)
name: Indium

fact: English word (The symbol derives from Latin stannum)
name: Tin

fact: Latin antimonium, the origin of which is uncertain: folk etymologies suggest it is derived from Greek anti ('against') + monos ('alone'), or Old French anti-moine, 'Monk's bane', but it could be from or related to Arabic _itmid, 'antimony', reformatted as a Latin word. (The symbol derives from Latin stibium 'stibnite'.)
name: Antimony

fact: Greek xenon, neuter form of xenos 'strange'
name: Xenon

fact: the dwarf planet Ceres, considered a planet at the time
name: Cerium

fact: samarskite, a mineral named after Colonel Vasili Samarsky-Bykhovets, Russian mine official
name: Samarium

fact: gadolinite, a mineral named after Johan Gadolin, Finnish chemist, physicist and mineralogist
name: Gadolinium

fact: Thule, the ancient name for an unclear northern location
name: Thulium

fact: King Tantalus, father of Niobe from Greek mythology
name: Tantalum

fact: Swedish tung sten, 'heavy stone' (The symbol is from wolfram, the old name of the tungsten mineral wolframite)
name: Tungsten

fact: Iris, the Greek Goddess of the rainbow
name: Iridium

fact: English word (The symbol derives from Latin aurum)
name: Gold

fact: Mercury, Roman God of commerce, communication, and luck, known for his speed and mobility (The symbol is from the element's Latin name hydrargyrum, derived from Greek hydrargyros, ater-silver')
name: Mercury

fact: English word (The symbol derives from Latin plumbum)
name: Lead

fact: German Wismut, from weiss Masse 'white mass', unless from Arabic
name: Bismuth

fact: Latin Polonia, 'Poland' (the home country of Marie Curie)
name: Polonium

fact: Thor, the Scandinavian God of thunder
name: Thorium

fact: proto- (from Greek protos, 'first, before') + actinium, which is produced through the radioactive decay of protactinium
name: Protactinium

fact: Uranus, the seventh planet in the Solar System
name: Uranium

fact: Neptune, the eighth planet in the Solar System
name: Neptunium

fact: the dwarf planet Pluto, considered the ninth planet in the Solar System at the time
name: Plutonium

fact: The Americas, as the element was first synthesised on the continent, by analogy with europium
name: Americium

fact: Pierre Curie and Marie Curie, French physicists and chemists
name: Curium

fact: Berkeley, California, where the element was first synthesised, by analogy with terbium
name: Berkelium

fact: California, where the element was first synthesised
name: Californium

fact: Dmitri Mendeleev, Russian chemist and inventor who proposed the periodic table
name: Mendelevium

fact: Alfred Nobel, Swedish chemist and engineer
name: Nobelium

fact: Ernest Rutherford, chemist and physicist from New Zealand
name: Rutherfordium

fact: Dubna, Russia, where the Joint Institute for Nuclear Research is located
name: Dubnium

fact: New Latin Hassia, 'Hesse' (a state in Germany)
name: Hassium

fact: Darmstadt, Germany, where the element was first synthesised
name: Darmstadtium

fact: Japanese Nihon, 'Japan' (where the element was first synthesised)
name: Nihonium

fact: Flerov Laboratory of Nuclear Reactions, part of JINR, where the element was synthesised; itself named after Georgy Flyorov, Russian physicist
name: Flerovium

fact: Moscow Oblast, Russia, where the element was first synthesised
name: Moscovium

fact: Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in Livermore, California, which collaborated with JINR on its synthesis
name: Livermorium
